qas.question: What political feeling is still a minority view in Britain?
What state of affairs produced revelations and problems for Elizabeth?
In spite of criticisms what kind of approval ratings did Elizabeth have?
What institution was being criticized during the time of Charles and Diana's breakup?
When did Elizabeth write to tell Charles and Diana to get a divorce?
What was the majority viewpoint politically in the 1990s in Britain?
In what year did Charles and Diana finally get divorced?
What type of approval ratings did Prime Minister John Major have?
In what year did Robert Fellowes become Elizabeth's private secretary?
In what year did George Carey become the Archbishop of Canterbury?

context: In the years to follow, public revelations on the state of <a1_0>Charles and Diana's marriage<a1_0/> continued. Even though support for republicanism in Britain seemed higher than at any time in living memory, <a0_0><b5_0>republicanism<b5_0/><a0_0/> was still a minority viewpoint, and the Queen herself had <a2_0><b7_0>high<b7_0/><a2_0/> approval ratings. Criticism was focused on the institution of the <a3_0>monarchy<a3_0/> itself and the Queen's wider family rather than her own behaviour and actions. In consultation with her husband and the Prime Minister, John Major, as well as the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, and her private secretary, Robert Fellowes, she wrote to Charles and Diana at the end of <a4_0>December <b6_0><b8_0><b9_0>1995<b9_0/><b8_0/><b6_0/><a4_0/>, saying that a divorce was desirable.
